ai_page.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Croydon - Page
ai_page.body:
Improvements and alterations

You must get our permission in writing before carrying out improvements or alterations to any part of a council owned or managed property. Depending on the type of alteration or improvement, you might also need planning permission or building regulations approval before work can begin. More information can be found in the guide to leasehold home improvements (PDF, 1.28MB).

Request approval for improvements or alterations

To request approval please complete the online form below.

ai_business_case.title: Apply to make change to a council flat - Croydon - Business Case
ai_business_case.letter:
To: CEO

From: Web Usability Manager

Subject: Recommendations for Enhancing the Council’s Online Tenant Service Platform

After reviewing the recent customer feedback, needs analysis, and the website content related to council tenant improvements, I have identified specific areas where targeted enhancements can significantly improve user experience, streamline processes, and generate cost savings for the council.

Positive Feedback Recognition:
Firstly, it’s worth noting that the current web pages successfully provide essential contact information and guidance for tenants like David. The clarity of contact channels is good, which helps in maintaining open lines of communication. Congratulations to the web team for establishing a foundation of accessible contact options.

Areas for Improvement & Strategic Recommendations:

1. Clarify Language to Improve Formality and User Understanding
Issue:
The phrase “get our permission in writing” may be perceived as informal or slightly ambiguous.

Recommendation:
Rephrase to “obtain written permission” throughout the page content.

Impact:
Adopting more formal, clearer language will enhance user trust in the process, reduce misinterpretations, and facilitate compliance, ultimately decreasing the need for follow-up clarifications and saving staff time.

2. Make Step-by-Step Instructions Explicit and User-Friendly
Issue:
Current guidance states “complete the online form below,” but does not specify that users need to upload photos or plans, nor does it walk them through the process.

Recommendation:
Update instructions to explicitly mention:
- Filling out the online form
- Uploading relevant photos or plans
- Confirmation of receipt after submission

Impact:
Providing clear, step-by-step guidance streamlines the user journey, reduces frustration, and lowers the volume of support queries. This not only enhances user satisfaction but also reduces staff workload and associated costs.

3. Include Estimated Timelines and Clear Contact Guidance
Issue:
While contact details are provided, there’s no information regarding expected response times, which raises concerns about delays.

Recommendation:
Add estimated response times and specify available hours for contact, e.g.:
- Response expected within 5 working days
- Contact for urgent inquiries available Monday to Friday, 9am–5pm

Impact:
Transparency around timelines reassures tenants like David, reduces follow-up inquiries, and improves perceived service reliability. This improvement can decrease unnecessary calls and emails, saving administrative resources.

Overall Impact:
Implementing these improvements will create a more transparent, user-centric online service that better meets tenant needs. Such enhancements can lead to increased efficiency, lower administrative costs, and a stronger perception of responsive municipal services. Over time, this can also promote greater digital engagement, reducing the reliance on paper correspondence and in-person visits.

I recommend prioritizing these updates in the upcoming website review cycle. Doing so will position the council as a forward-thinking authority that values clear communication and accessible services, all while optimizing operational efficiency.

Respectfully submitted,

[Your Name]
Web Usability Manager
